qa.question: What do you mainly use your phone for?
qa.answer: I use my phone mostly for WhatsApp. My customers send me blouse designs, measurements, and sometimes payment details there. I also watch stitching videos on YouTube, and sometimes listen to songs. I don’t use it for bank apps—I go to the ATM to check balance.

qa.question: Do you share your phone with others?
qa.answer: Yes, I share it with my daughter. She helps me check WhatsApp when I don’t understand something. She also uses YouTube on it. But otherwise, no one else uses my phone.

qa.question: What are your favorite apps or features on your phone?
qa.answer: I like WhatsApp because it helps with work. YouTube is also good for seeing new designs. I’ve never thought about what they collect from me. I didn’t know they can take anything.

qa.question: When an app asks for permission, like to access your location or camera, do you read and understand what it means?
qa.answer: No, I don’t understand it. I ask my daughter. Sometimes I just press ‘Allow’ to make it work.

qa.question: How do you decide whether an app or website is safe to use?
qa.answer: I only use what my daughter or brother tells me to. I don’t download anything by myself.

qa.question: Have you ever deleted a message, photo, or app because you didn’t want someone to see it?
qa.answer: Yes, sometimes if I get an unnecessary message from someone I don’t know, I delete it so my husband doesn’t think wrong.

qa.question: If your phone stops working and you need to give it for repair, what do you do before handing it over?
qa.answer: I try to delete customer photos and messages. I don’t know how to remove everything, but I delete what I can.

qa.question: Have you ever asked someone to help you with a phone problem?
qa.answer: Yes, my daughter or my brother. I feel shy when they open my phone and see personal things, so I tell them not to check my photos.

qa.question: Who do you trust most when sharing personal or sensitive information?
qa.answer: Only in person. I don’t send anything important on the phone. If I have to, I call the person directly.

qa.question: Have you used code words or nicknames to keep something private?
qa.answer: Sometimes, I save customer names with a code so my husband doesn’t ask too many questions.

qa.question: Have you ever helped someone install or use an app?
qa.answer: No, I usually ask for help. I’m not confident in teaching others about phones.

qa.question: Do you know how to stop an app from using your camera, microphone, or location?
qa.answer: No, I don’t know how to do that.

qa.question: When you get a warning message (‘this app may harm your phone’), what do you usually do?
qa.answer: I show it to my daughter. I don’t install anything that gives such a warning.

qa.question: What do you think happens when you give an app access to your contacts or photos?
qa.answer: I didn’t know they can take my contacts or photos. That’s scary.

qa.question: Have you ever hesitated to take your phone for repair because of private content?
qa.answer: Yes, I worry they will see my photos or customer messages, so I delete some of them before going.

qa.question: Has a repair person ever opened your gallery or apps without asking?
qa.answer: I’m not sure, but once a man at the shop was touching things quickly. I felt uncomfortable.

qa.question: Do you use a password or lock screen on your phone? Why or why not?
qa.answer: No, it’s difficult for me to remember. But my daughter says I should.

qa.question: Do you think local apps are safer than international ones? Why?
qa.answer: I don’t know the difference. I just use what my daughter installs.

qa.question: Who do you turn to when you don’t understand a phone or app setting?
qa.answer: My daughter or brother. They know more about phones.

qa.question: Do people around you influence how you think about online safety?
qa.answer: Yes, my brother tells me not to click on random messages. He says many are fake.

scenarios.Broken Phone: I delete my customer photos and messages. I feel nervous giving the phone to the shop. I ask my brother to talk to them if needed.
scenarios.Sharing with Family: If a message comes while my daughter is using the phone, I ask her to give it back. I don’t want her to see everything.
scenarios.New App Requesting Permissions: I would ask my daughter what it means. I don’t say yes or no without asking her.
scenarios.Helping Elderly Relative: I don’t help others with apps, but if someone older asked me, I would ask my daughter to help both of us.
scenarios.Using Someone Else’s Phone: I would not look at anything private. That’s not right.
scenarios.Giving Away Phone: I would delete photos and messages, and ask my daughter if she can erase everything else.
scenarios.Cloud Backup Surprise: I don’t know what cloud is. If I saw my old photos again, I would be confused.
scenarios.Free Public WiFi: I’ve never used it. I don’t know how. I use my phone data only.
scenarios.Lottery Call: I once got such a call. I gave my brother the phone, and he told me it was fake.
scenarios.Friend Needs Help: If it’s someone I trust, I would give money if I have. But only after talking to them myself.
